text:
today on hot Thai kitchen we are making 
kao mun gai Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai

kitchen today we're making one of the most 
popular street foods in Thailand and that

is kao mun gai known in english as Hainanese 
chicken rice and that's because the island

of Hainan is where this dish was originated 
from and I'm particularly fond of this dish

because my grandmother was actually born and 
raised in Hainan so she pretty much makes this

dish every time I see her so now I'm going to 
share it with you so first your Thai listen

what does kao mun gai mean kao mun means fatty 
rice and it refers to the fact that we're going

to cook our rice and chicken fat and gai means 
chicken so let's take a look at our ingredients

so here's our chicken now I like to get my 
chicken at an Asian butcher because then I

get the feet in the head and everything so I have 
more stock material so our cooking water will be

more flavorful now this particular chicken is 
what they call Ching ping chicken which means

that they're free-range they were active so the 
meat is quite flavorful but they're also smaller

this guy is about two and a half pounds which 
is actually perfect so I'm going to first cut

off his head and his feet so we're going to take 
that but I'm going to save the skin because the

skin around the neck has a lot of fat which I want 
to then render for our rice so in goes the head

cut off his feet I'm going to crack the bones a 
little bit just to help the the bones release the

flavor a little quicker okay and now what I'm 
going to do is collect chicken fat we want as

much as possible for our rice usually there's a 
bunch around the skin around the neck flap right

here so there see that that usually comes from the 
next we want to save that in the cavity by the bum

there's a bunch you can collect one last check to 
see if I left anything I'll deal with that later

I know it doesn't look very good right now but 
in here we're also going to add all of our stock

aromatics and that's all our cilantro roots ginger 
garlic and white peppercorns that I've crushed

and also our onions and we're basically going 
to get this to a quick boil to sort of render

the stock so that then we can cook our chicken 
in something flavorful so at this point you can

cook your chicken just like this or you can brine 
the chicken if you've got the time and you want

to make it extra juicy if you're going to brine 
it though I'm going to make a very dilute brine

solution so what I do is one gallon of water to 
about two tablespoons of salt which is not very

salty at all because you don't want the chicken 
meat to be too well-seasoned we're going to make

a really delicious dipping sauce it's quite salty 
so the chicken meat is already well seasoned then

the whole thing is just overkill so about two 
hours for a small chicken like this is an American

standard size chicken three to four hours is good 
in cold cold brine so we're going to wait for that

stock to come to a simmer and let it go for about 
20 minutes or so and then we're going to go cook

our chicken I almost forgot you want to remove the 
wishbone from the chicken first and the wishbone

is basically the collar bone of the chicken you 
don't absolutely have to take it out but if you

don't it'll get in the way of when you go to carve 
out the chicken breast and basically you want to

sit the chicken up so that it's full it would 
be facing me but I going to face you so that you

can see it and you can feel the bones right here 
and scrape it until the bones is exposed see that

so once the bones are sort of exposed and then 
you're just going to take your fingers and pull

it off and it broke so I've got two pieces now 
kind of loosen the meat that's sort of holding

on to the bones around this part come on there we 
go so that goes also into the stockpot and now we

can move on so our stock has been simmering for 
about twenty minutes or so just to get basically

to render a base stocks or chicken has a flavorful 
liquid to cook in and I'm going to season this

stock now this cooking liquid about a tablespoon 
two tablespoon and a half again you don't want

this to be too salty because this is the stock 
we're going to use to cook our rice in as well

and I'm going to add some cold water to bring the 
temperature down so he's not shocked when he goes

in to the hot water Oh at this point you can also 
taste the water it's going to add a little more

salt unless you do it now you want to start the 
cooking water not hot because if you start them

in hot water the outside will cook a lot faster 
than the inside so if you start it cold and bring

the temperature up together the chicken will cook 
more evenly throughout and then I'm going to top

him off a little so he's nicely submerged so we're 
going to bring the water temperature up to 165 to

170 degrees and keep it there so a thermometer 
like this I think this is a lot a thermometer I

found no idea where I got that from just to help 
you gauge the water temperature if you don't have

a thermometer you want to look for the water to 
be completely still so there should be no bubbling

no nothing but this there's steam coming off the 
top all the time that's what 160 570 degree water

looks like so without a thermometer you could 
still do this in Thailand that's what they do

is they call it boil chicken in Stillwater so 
that's what that means the temperature we need

the chicken eventually to be at is 165 degrees 
so if we keep the water there we make sure the

chicken does not overcook does not dry out any 
more than it absolutely has to we're going to come

and flip this chicken halfway through so for this 
guy he's going to take about 30 minutes because

he's a small chicken and the time starts after the 
water has reset temperature so don't start timing

until you're at 165 and then if you're doing a 
bigger chicken you'll probably need 45 maybe 50

minutes just depends on a lot of factors so we're 
going to come back what do you think we're going

to get our rice started by remember a lovely 
chicken fat that we collected well here it is

and we're going to render a fat you want to turn 
the heat down low because you don't want this skin

and everything to start burning and sticking to 
the bottom and you want to keep stirring because

otherwise the skin will stick to the bottom if you 
don't have enough chicken fat your chickens very

lean or you just don't feel good eating a lot 
of chicken fat you can use either all vegetable

oil or a combination of both a lot of times if 
I get a chicken that doesn't have a lot of fat

I just add a little vegetable oil in there just 
to get it to where I need so our chicken fat is

starting to collect now you can see if you've 
got a particularly abundant fatty chicken you

can stop whenever you've got about I'd say if 
you have about two to three tablespoons of fat

that should be enough for 2 cups of rice which 
I'm going to make you can also fry these all

the way to crispy and snack on it if you want and 
to this I'm going to add chopped garlic and just

until the garlic is nice and golden mmm garlicky 
chicken fat the smallest bits are starting to turn

golden brown I'm going to add my rice which I 
have rinsed twice and drained very very well

awesome and then I'm just going to coat the 
rice in this garlicky fatty goodness now

normally you would wait for your chicken to 
be done before you start doing this because

you need the chicken cooking water to cook the 
rice but I've got chicken cooking water from

my previous batch and then I'm going to go in 
with my stock two and two-thirds cup of stock

so that's one and one-third parts stock to one 
part rice you may need more or less depending

on your particular rice or how soft or firm 
you like your rice to be I've done it up to

three cups of water to two cups of rice and 
that yields very soft nice soft rice but you

can always add you see you can take away so 
if you're not sure start with less and you

can always add more we're going to stir it 
until the rice is thick now you're wondering

why why can I just throw all this in a rice 
cooker and you could and people do but you

see all this fat that is floated to the top if 
I let this rice cook right now like I normally

do with the rice cooker all the fat will end 
up coating all the rice on the top and then

there it won't be evenly distributed so I like 
to stir it until the rice is thick enough that

the fat can be held down by the thickness of 
the rice you see what I mean when we get there

there's my chicken timer so that means I have 
to flip my chicken but I'll deal with that in

a second because our rice is at its critical 
moment okay see how now it's kind of thick

pudding ish that's what we want that's what 
we're looking for are going to keep stirring

until there see how now the fat is staying 
down because the rice is thick enough to

hold it down so give it a good stir distribute 
that fat and now turn it down to very very low

close it up and now scrape that off and now 
you're just going to let it cook like you

would regular rice so let it go for about 
10 to 15 minutes until all the liquid has

been absorbed then the rice looks done on the 
top and then turn it off and we're going to let

it sit and sort of steam in its own heat for 
another 10 minutes or so before research and

now the most important part the dipping sauce you 
can actually find common Chi in a few different

Asian countries but each country seems to have 
their own unique dipping sauce so of course I'm

going to show you the ones that are common in 
Thailand but I actually show you two the first

one is the one that you commonly find at most 
Calvin gai places so here are your ingredients

and now you can do this either in a blender 
or in a mortar and pestle ginger and garlic

first sorry ginger and what are those red 
things called Chili's that's right get it

to about that consistency - so there are 
no more big chunks it doesn't have to be

a complete mush and then you're going to 
go in with fermented soybean paste which I

used before in my Ratna video and it comes in a 
bottle like this okay and it usually is kind of

chunky still has whole soybeans in it so we're 
going to just crush it but now that you've got

liquid in there you don't want to pound it 
or you'll get it in your face you're going

to add some sugar and at this point to help it 
grind now every restaurant will have their own

version of this dipping sauce but the must-have 
ingredients for any place is the 3000 and the

next thing I'm going to add which is Cu them 
or black soy sauce okay see you demand and 3000

are the two main ingredients you must have and 
then you know everything else is sort of their

own thing so see oh damn black soy sauce comes 
in a bottle like this it's not very salty it's

mostly sweet if you need help finding it let me 
know regular soy sauce finally a little bit of

vinegar I'm just using a teaspoon if you want a 
little tartar you can add more give it a taste

perfect mainly salty now some people do garlic 
instead of ginger quite prominently sweet but

the salty is still the leading flavor recipe 
number two it's the one that my grandmother

always makes and it's what she tells me 
it's the traditional Hainanese dipping

sauce it's little brighter and lighter 
and more citrusy so here's what you meat

and this dipping sauce you 
just pound everything together

really bright and garlicky and gingery and spicy 
mmm so good that'll be good on anything so our

chicken is should be done it's been 30 minutes so 
we're going to check temperature at around this

part here and by the way don't allow for residual 
cooking for this guy because we're cooking the

chicken at such a low temperature as as soon as 
you take the chicken out the temperature will

drop right away so a we're at some 165 that's 
good benefit of using a small chicken is you

can take him out pretty easily and now we're 
going to let this sit until it's cooled down to

basically room temperature this thing is served at 
room temperature normally at this point you then

take the stock and cook your rice with it so and 
then while the rice cooks chicken could cool down

it all works out really well this stock also you 
want to serve as a soup on the side so you want to

taste the stock at this point it should be mildly 
salted it shouldn't be salty because it's going to

serve as a palate cleanser between the salty fatty 
bites so some people like to add some winter melon

or other vegetables to it I like it to keep it 
this sort of plain so there let's let this cool

down and then we're going to butcher him next just 
carve the chicken like you normally would if you

want to see how I do it you can click the link in 
the description or in the end ok so now is where

the cleaver comes in handy because then you're 
able to cut the chicken quickly and you won't

mess up the skin use none of this sawing stuff and 
it's also fun so you just go and in Thailand they

like to Pat it down so it's flat and makes it look 
like there's more chicken than there really is but

you don't need to do that so take that put it on 
your rice by the way your rice if halfway if by

the end it's cooking and the top part still a 
little bit hard you can drizzle a little more

stock and let keep it cooking a little bit more 
don't need to stir it up or anything okay so let's

and now you can serve the sauce on the 
side or you can drizzle it on like I

like to do and I like to double sauce 
it because this is sweet and salty and

the other one is sour and gingery so 
it kind of goes together really well

most places will not by the way have two 
different sauces for you let's taste it

that is really good that's better than some 
of the streets for the common guy I've had

the chicken is super tender because we cook 
it at such a low temperature that it really

didn't have any opportunity to dry out so 
it's perfect I didn't even brine this one

so you can imagine how tender brined chicken 
will be in the sauce a combination of the two

a perfect combination of spicy sweet sour 
salty that's all it's all very good so if

you want to try you can visit my website 
for the recipe at ign.com if you enjoy the

show please to subscribe and I will see you
